CHAP. III.

An act for allowing further time to persons in offices or employments, to qualify themselves pursuant to an all, intituled an act to prevent. the further growth of popery.

WHEREAS several persons well affected to his Majesty's government, and P,foM, M.

the church of Ireland, as by law established, may have through ignorance lifting by nt neglected, or been prevented by sickness or other unavoidable causes from taking and subscribing the oaths, and making and subscribing the declaration, and from a Ac*, < 6. in-receiving the sacrament of the lord’s supper, according to the directions of an act dcinn^<;' made in this kingdom in the second year of the reign of her late Majesty Queen Anne, intituled, an act ti prevent she further growth of popery, and by their inadvertency may have incurred great penalties: be it enacted by the king’s most excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, that all and cvety person or persons, who have incurred any penalties and incapacities in the said act, intituled, an act to prevent the further Growth of popery, mentioned, by neglecting to qualify themselves according to the said Act, shall be and are hereby indemnified, freed, and discharged of and from all incapacities, disabilities, forfeitures, and penalties incurred by reason of such omission or neglect as aforesaid j and that no act or acts done by them, or any of them, or by authority derived from them, or any of them, and not yet avoided, shall be quell ioned or avoided by reason of such neglect or omission; but all such acts shall be and are hereby declared and enabled to be as good' and effectual, as if all and every such person and persons had taken and subscribed the said oaths, and received the said sacrament, and made and subscribed the said declaration in manner as aforesaid; any thing in the said act to the contrary notwithstanding: provided such person or persons do and shall take and subscribe the said oaths, and receive the said sacrament, and make, repeat, and fuh-feribe the said declaration in such manner and form, and in such place and places, as are directed and appointed by the said act to prevent the further growth of popery, on or before the first day of August, which shall be in the year of our Lord one thousand seven hundred and seventy-four.

CHAP. V.

An act to prevent combinations to raise the price of coals in the city of Dublin,

WHEREAS several unlawful combinations have been en-entered into to raise the price of coals in the city of Dublin, to the great prejudice of the publick; for remedy whereof, and to prevent the like for the future, be it enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal, and commons in this present parliament assembled, and by the authority of the No allow- fame> that from and after the twelfth day of May one thousand ance by maf- seven hundred and seventy-one no matter, owner, or mate of o^mitcof any coal ship or vessel within the port or city of Dublin, shall M/fofor£?vei or promise to give, any fee, gratuity, reward, or allowance felling coals whatsoever to any factor, purser, agent, or other person for felling of any coals; and that no factor, purser, agent, or other or" "rafted Person> shall receive, or contract to receive, from any matter, for, owner, or mate of any such coal (hiporveflel, any fee, gratuity, reward, or allowance whatsoever, for felling of any coals; and that every person who shall, after the time aforesaid, offend herein, shall, 100l. for every such offence forfeit the sum of one hundred pounds, as by i G. to be recovered and applied in the manner directed by an act 3>0 I0' passed

The eleventh year of George III.

passed in the first year of his present Majesty's reign, intituled, an act to prevent the excessive price of Coats in the city of Dublin.

II. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that from and after the time aforesaid no person or persons whatl'o-ever, except the master or mates of such coal ships or vessels, and the persons authorized by the said act, shall fell any coals within the port or city of Dublin 5 and that every person offending herein shall for every such offence forfeit the sum of fifty pounds, to be recovered and applied in tire manner herein before mentioned.

III. And whereas several large coal ships or vessels draw too much water to pass Ring’s-End point, and the matters and owners ofgabbards and lighters frequently refuse to bring the coals from such ships or vessels to the quays of the city of Dublin, unless an allowance, called the Old Man, is made to them j be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, that no matters, owners, or mate of any such ship or vessel, shall after the time aforesaid give, or promise to give, to any matter or owner of such gab-bard or lighter, or other person, any fee, gratuity, reward, or allowance whatsoever, except freight, not exceeding the rate of one shilling and six pence per ton, for carrying any coals from such /hips or vessels to the quays; and that no matter or owners of any gabbard or lighter, or other person, shall receive, or contract to receive, any fee, gratuity, reward, or allowance whatsoever, except freight, not exceeding the rate aforesaid, for carrying any coals from such ships or vessels to the said quays; and that every person offending herein shall forfeit for every such offence the sum of fifty pounds, to be recovered and applied as herein before is mentioned*

IV. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that all coals, which shall be brought into the said city of Dublin from any colliery in this kingdom by means of any inland canal, made or to be made in this kingdom, shall be considered as imported into the said city; and the master or owner so importing the same shall be intitled to all premiums and encouragements granted for bringing Irish coals into the said city.

V. Provided always, and be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, that this act shall continue in force until the twenty fourth day of June one thousand seven hundred and seventy four, and to the end of the then next session of parliament.

CHAP. VI.

An act to prevent the pernicious practice of turning tricks 'within the dtp of Dublin, or the neighbourhood thereof.

WHEREAS large quantities of bricks are frequently burned within the city of Dublin, and in the neighbourhood thereof, by means whereof the inhabitants of the said city are grievously annoyed, and the lives of many weakly persons have been loft: for remedy thereof be it enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this preterit Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, that from and after the tenth day of May one thousand seven hundred and seventy one no person shall make, or cause to be made, burn, or cause to be burned, any bricks within the distance of two measured miles from the publick lamps of the city of Dublin, 'on pain of forfeiting the bricks, and ten findings for every thousand bricks made or burned within the aforesaid limits.

II. And be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, that upon complaint, made before two or more justices within their respective jurisdictions, such justices are hereby authorized and required to summon the person or persons so complained of before them, and upon appearance or default of the person or persons so complained of, and due proof of such offence by the oath of one or more credible witness or witnesses, to convict such offender or offenders, and to order by warrant under their hands and seals the bricks to be sold by public cant, and the said penalty of ten shillings per thousand to be levied by distress. and sale of the offenders goods.

III. And be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, that one moiety of said penalty, and of the produce of the bricks, shall, after, deducting the necessary expences attending the sale of the bricks and levying the penalty, be paid to the first: informer, the other moiety to the governors of Mercer’s hospital for the use of said hospital; and for want of sufficient distress such justices are hereby authorized and required to commit the person or persons so offending to the common gaol of the city, or county, there to remain without bail or mainprize for any term not exceeding three months.

IV. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the parishioners and inhabitants of the parish, liberty, or pre-

CHAP. VII.

An act for full fling such persons as fiall do injuries and violences to the persons or properties of his Majests subjects, with intent to hinder the exportation of corn.

WHEREAS many disorderly and evil minded persons have of late frequently assembled themselves in great numbers, and committed great violences, and done many injuries to the persons and properties of his Majesty's subjects, with intent to hinder the exportation of corn or potatoes, or the carriage thereof from one part of this kingdom to another, whereby many of his Majesty's subjects have been deterred from buying corn and grain, and potatoes, and following their lawful business therein, to their great loss and damage, as well as the great damage and prejudice of the farmers and landlords of this kingdom, and of the nation in general: for the better preventing such wicked and disorderly practices, and more easily and effectually bringing such offenders to condign punishment, be it enacted by the King's most excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, that if any person shall from and after the first day of June next wilfully and maliciously beat, wound,

or use any other violence to or upon any person or persons with hinder buying intent to deter or hinder him or them from buying of corn, or 0"^ grain, or potatoes, in any market or other place within this kingdom, or shall unlawfully flop or seize upon any waggon, cait, or other carriage, or horse loaded with wheat, flour, meal, malt, or other grain, or potatoes, in or on the way to or from any city, market town, seaport, or other usual place of Hupping or hoifc To ’ corn or potatoes in this kingdom, or wilfully and maliciously 1"> break, cut, separate, or destroy the fame, or any part thereof, place for iiup-or the hamefs of the horses drawing the fame, or shall unlaw- '""s' fully take off, drive away, kill or wound any of such horses, or un- ildlro)’ any lawfully beat or wound the driver or drivers of such waggon, cart, J*j)orl,ar' or other carriage or horse so loaded, in order to flop the fame, take off, or shall by cutting the sacks. or otherwise scaster or throw abroad VMuwihorf«,

CHAP. VIII.

An act to repeal an act, intituled, an act for the relief of debtors, with respect to the imprisonment of their persons.

WHEREAS an act of parliament made in the eighth year 8 G- 3 Ci of his present Majesty's reign, intituled, an act for the *5. affeaing relief of debtors, with respect to the imprisonment of their persons, has Sit, trade, been found by experience greatly to affect personal credit, and prejudicial to the trades and manufactures of this kingdom 3 be pealed, it therefore enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent.of the lords spiritual and temporal, and commons in this present parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, that the aforesaid act, and every clause thereof, be henceforth repealed, and made null and void.

IV. And' whereas great inconvenience has been felt in tilt province of Ulster, from a difficulty in finding collectors disqualified to Collect the publick money, pursuant to an act passed in the fifth year of his present Majesty, intituled, an act for amending the publick roads, by which great arrears have incurred within several baronies, to the great interruption and delay of such Work; be it therefore enacted by the authority aforesaid, that as often as the grand jury of any county in the said province of Ulster shall neglect or omit to- appoint a collector pursuant to said statute for any barony or baronies in said county, that the treasurer of such county shall issue his warrant to the high constable of such barony or baronies, requiring him to levy such sum as shall be celled and applotted on the barony within his district, together with any firm that may have remained in arrear on such barony by any former neglect of appointing a collector; which warrant the said high constable is hereby impowered and required to execute, and to collect and levy the sum so applotted off the barony as aforesaid, and to pay over the same to the treasurer of the county, on or before the first day of the next ensuing assizes j and such high constable shall be allowed for his trouble in collecting the fame sixpence in the pound, in like manner as the collectors appointed by grand juries.

CHAP. XI.

An act to oblige ships more efeBually to perform their Quarantine, and for the better preventing the plague being brought from foreign parts into Ireland, and to hinder the Jpreading of infeBion.

WHEREAS the laws heretofore made in this kingdom to oblige ships coming from places infected to perform quarantine, and to prevent the plague being brought into and spreading in the kingdom of Ireland, are expired, and it is necessary, that some provision be made by parliament for obliging ships and persons, coming from places infected with of frequently subject to the plague, to perform quarantine in such Vol. X. III. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that if any commander,- master, or other person having charge of any ship or vessel liable to perform quarantine, having notice thereof, shall himself quit, or shall knowingly permit or suffer any seaman or passenger coming in such ship or vessel, to quit, such ship or vessel,- by going on shore, or by going on board any other ship, boat, or vessel, before such quarantine shall be fully performed, unless in such cases, and by such proper licence, as shall be directed or permitted by such order or orders, made or to be made concerning quarantine, and the prevention of infection, and notified as aforesaid; or in case any commander, master, or other person having charge of such ship or vessel, shall not, within convenient time after due notice given for that purpose by the proper officer, cause such ship or vessel, and the lading thereof, to be conveyed into the place or places appointed for such ship, vessel, and lading, to perform quarantine respectively, then and in every such case every such commander, master, or other person having charge of such ship or vessel, for every such offence shall forfeit the sum of five hundred pounds, one moiety thereof to the king, his heirs and successors, and the other moiety to him or them who shall sue for the same; and also if any person shall so quit such ship or vessel by going on shore, or by going on board any other ship or vessel, contrary to the true meaning of this act,

V. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that, the proper officers authorized to put in execution such orders, made or to be made and notified as aforesaid, shall, and they are hereby impowered and required, to cause and compel all persons obliged to perform quarantine as aforesaid, and all goods and merchandizes comprized within any. such orders made, or to be made, and notified as aforesaid, respectively to repair or be conveyed to some of the said {hips, houses, or lazarets, sheds, tents, or other places, provided as aforesaid, according to such order, or orders made, or to be made, and notified as aforesaid.

VI. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that ifanyperson, obliged to perform quarantine as aforesaid, shall, wilfully refuse or neglect to repair within convenient time after; due notice, for that purpose given to him, her, or them, by the proper officer, to the ship, house, lazaret, or other place, duly, appointed for him, her, or them, or having been placed in such ship, house, or lazaret, or other place, shall escape, or attempt to escape, out of the fame, before quarantine fully performed, it shall and may be lawful to and for the watchmen, and other persons appointed to fee quarantine duly performed, by any kind of violence, that the case shall require, to compel every such person. so refusing or neglecting as aforesaid, and every such person so escaping, or attempting to escape as aforesaid, to repair or return into such ship, house, lazaret, or other place, so ap-appointed for him or her as. aforesaid; and every such person so refusing or neglecting to repair within convenient time after such notice, as aforesaid, into such ship, house, lazaret, or other place, appointed for him or her, as aforesaid. and also every person actually escaping, as aforesaid, shall be adjudged guilty of felony, and shall suffer death as a felon without benefit of clergy.

XV. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that if any officer or other person, appointed to fee quarantine duly performed, or any person placed or appointed as a watchman upon any ship, house, lazaret, or other place for performance of quarantine, in pursuance of this act, shall desert from his or their duty when employed on the said business of quarantine, or shall knowingly and willingly permit or suffer any person, ship, goods, or merchandizes, to depart or be conveyed out of such ship, house, lazaret, or other place respectively appointed for performance of quarantine, unless in such cases, and by such licence, as are or shall be directed or permitted by some order or orders made, or to be made, and notified by proclamation, as aforesaid, or if any person directed as aforesaid to give a certificate of a ship having duly performed her quarantine or airing, shall knowingly give a fade certificate, then, and in every of the said cases, every such officer, and persons so offending, shall be adjudged guilty of felony, and shall suffer death as in cases of felony without benefit of clergy.

XVIII. And to the end that all persons may know how to demean themselves in the premisses, be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that when and as often as the lord lieu-' tenant, or other chief governor or governors of this kingdom, shall make any order or orders concerning quarantine, and the prevention of infection, and notify the fame by proclamation as aforesaid, such proclamation shall be publickly read upon the next Sunday after the receipt of the fame, and the first Sunday in every month afterwards, during the time such order shall continue in force, immediately after the prayers, in all parish churches, and other places set apart for divine worship, within such counties and places as shall be specified for that purpose in such proclamation.

XIX. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that if any action or suit shall be commenced against any person or persons for any thing done in pursuance of this present act, the defendant or defendants in such action or suit may plead the general issue, and give this act and the special matter in evidence at any trial to be had thereupon, and that the same was done in pursuance and by the authority of the said act; and if it shall appear so to have been done, and the jury shall find for the defendant or defendants, and if the plaintiff shall be non-suited, or discontinue his action, after the defendant or defendant shall have appeared, or if judgment shall have been given upon any verdict or demurrer against the plaintiff, the defendant or defendants shall and may recover treble costs, and have the like remedy for the same, as the defendant or defendants hath or have, in other cases by law.

XX. Provided always, and be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, that no attainder of felony by virtue of this act shall extend to work any corruption of blood, or forfeiture of any goods, chattles, lands, tenements, or hereditaments.

XXI. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that this act, and the several clauses and provisoes therein contained, shall commence and take efteft from and after the first day of May in the year of our lord one thousand seven hundred and seventy one, and that the same shall continue in force for the space of seven years, and from thence to the end of the then next fcllion of parliament, and no longer.

WHEREAS the present mode of decision upon petitions, complaining of undue elections or returns of members to serve in parliament, frequently obstructs public business, occasions much expence, trouble, and delay to the parties, is defective for want of those sanctions and solemnities, which are established by law in other trials, and is attended with many other inconveniencies: for remedy thereof be it enacted by the king’s most excellent Majesty by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, wh pen'-that after the twenty-fourth day of June one thousand seven hundred and seventy-orie whenever a petition, complaining of fcLITtime an undue election or return of a member or members to serve "Route w in parliament, shall be presented to the house of commons, a day C0[ifiJer it. and hour shall by the said house be appointed for taking the notice in fame into consideration, and notice thereof in writing shall be forthwith given by the speaker to the petitioners and tire fitting plr,ics or members, or their respective agents, accompanied with an order ascms’ to them to attend the house at die time appointed by themselves, tomcniT their counsel or agents.

CHAP. XIII.

An act for continuing certain law, heretofore made fir the improvement of his Majesty's revenue, and the more effectual prevention of frauds therein.

WHERAS die several laws herein after mentioned, made for the improvement of his Majesty's revenue, and the more effectual prevention of frauds therein, have been found to be of general use, but are now near expiring; be it enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present parliament assembled, and by die authority of the same, that an act made in the thirty third year of the reign of his late 33 c.i,c. 10. CHAP. V.

An act for the niore effectual punifiing wicked and disorderly persons, who have committed, or shall commit, violences, and do injuries to the persons or properties of any of his Majesty's subjcBs in the counties of Antrim, Down, Armagh, city and county of Londonderry, and county of ’Tyrone, or any of them , or who shall deliver or publifl,’> threatening letters, or who reffl or oppose the levying the publick taxes in the said counties, or any of them j and for the more effectual bringing to justice certain offenders therein mentioned.

WH ER EAS by an act passed in this kingdom in the twenty ninth year of his late Majesty George the second it is amongst other things enacted, that from and after the first day of May one thousand seven hundred and fifty six if any person or persons Dial! unlawfully or maliciouOy set fire- to any house, out house, barn,- or liable, or to any haggard, Hack, or rick of corn, straw, hay, or turf, or to any ship or boat, although the same shall not be burned, or shall be procuring, aiding, or aflilting in any of said oifenecs, or in the wilful or malicious killing, maiming, or houghing any horses, horned cattle, or sheep, every person so offending, being legally convicted, shall be adjudged guilty of felony,

and shall fuifer death as in cases of felony without benefit of clergy; which said act has since been made perpetual: and whereas by another act, passed in this kingdom in the fifth year of his present Majesty, it is among! other things enacted, that any person or persons, who should by force or menaces impose or tender any oath or oaths, or any other solemn engagement, on any other person or persons in order thereby to compel him, her, or them, to commit or conceal any unlawful act or acts, should on conviction thereof be deemed guilty of felony without benefit of clergy: and whereas the offences against said acts have in defiance thereof been in a most outrageous manner lately committed in the said counties of Antrim, Down, Armagh, city and county of Londonderry, and county of Tyrone by a number of disorderly and wicked persons, who have entered into confederacies to attift and support each other, and have procured by threats and promises several of his Majesty's subjects to join with them; and have sent letters with fictitious names, and some without name, to several persons demanding arms and money; and have otherwise demanded arms, or forcibly, or by threats, taken and obtained arms from several of his Majesty's subjects, and have threatened violence, if such their unlawful demands shall be refitted, or if they should be prosecuted for such their wicked practices, and have in pursuance of such threats actually done great damage to several persons, who have either refitted to comply with such demands, or have endeavoured to bring them to justice, to the great terror of his Majesty's peaceable subjects, the hindrance of trade and industry, and the endangering of the peace and good government of this kingdom: therefore be it cnaCIcd by the King's most excellent Majesty by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, that if any person or persons in the said counties of Antrim, Down, Armagh, city and county of Londonderry, and county of Tyrone, or any of them, front and after the second day of April one thousand seven hundred and seventy-two shall maliciously and wilfully pull down or destroy, or begin to pull down or destroy, the houses or outhouses, or mills, warehouses, or other houses for trade or manufacture, of of any person or persons in any of the said counties, or shall knowingly fend, deliver, affix in any publick place, or otherwise publifl), or cause to be so sent, delivered.

XII. Provided always, that no person shall be entitled to recover such his damage to be sustained as aforesaid, unless it shall appear to the grand jury and the court, who are to confirm such presentment, that the person claiming to be satisfied for such damage by himself or his servant, or other person appointed by him for that purpose, within twenty four hours after the mischief so done to such person’s property, did give notice to some of the inhabitants of the town or village next to the place, where such offence shall be committed; and shall within four days after give information by the oath of himself, or fume of his servants, or other persons bell acquainted therewith, before some neighbouring magistrate, concerning said offence, and shall become bound himself, or procure such other persons to become bound before said magistrate for the prosecuting all or any of the persons, who shall appear to be any way concerned in said offences, at the next assizes to be held for said county.

XIII. Provided, that if any persons shall find themselves aggrieved by any presentment to be made in pursuance of this act, such persons, in case the sum presented to be raised do exceed twenty pounds, may at said assizes traverse the presentment thereof, which traverse shall be tried at the fame or next assizes, as the judge, who shall allow the fame, may think (it; and if on the trial of such traverse, the issue shall be found for the traversers, such presentment shall be discharged; and if the issue shall thereupon be found against the traveller, they shall pay to the persons, on whose behalf the presentment was made, five pounds for cods, and said presentment shall be thereupon conclusive to all parties.

CHAP. VIII.

An act to prevent frauds committed bp bankrupts

WHEREAS divers persons actually exercising the trade of merchandize in gross or by retail, seeking their living by buying and selling, as also scriveners, falefmasters, bankers, brokers, and factors, as well natural born subjects as denizens and aliens, do frequently abscond, and keep their houses, or otherwise seek to evade the payment of their just' debts not so much by reason of actual losses or unavoidable misfortunes, as to the intent to defraud their creditors, and oftentimes make conveyances of their estates and effects, and execute bonds and other securities, to some in prejudice to others of their creditors: and whereas many well disposed persons by the casualties, to which trade is liable, are frequently laid under grievous hardships by the obduracy of one or more creditor or creditors, and are thereby prevented from doing that equal justice to their creditors in general, which they are willing to do: for remedy whereof be it enacted by the king’s most excellent Majesty by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present parliament assembled, and by the authority Merchant* of the fame, that from and after the twenty fourth day of June ^pofsorrc- year of our ior(j one thousand seven hundred and seventy

XLIX. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that if any bankrupt, who shall have obtained his or her certificates from the acting commissioners, and such certificate shall have been allowed and confirmed, as by this act is directed, shall be taken in execution or detained in prison on account of any debt, due or owing before he or she became bankrupt, by reason that judgment was obtained, before such certificate was allowed and confirmed, it shall and may be lawful to and for any one or more of the judges of the court, wherein judgment shall have been so obtained against such bankrupt, on such bankrupt’s producing his or her certificate allowed and confirmed, to order any sheriff, or sheriffs bailiff, or officer, gaoler, or keeper of any prison, who shall have any such bankrupt in his custody by virtue of any such execution, to discharge such bankrupt out of custody on such execution without payment of any fee or reward j and such sheriff, or sheriffs bailiff, or officer, gaoler, or keeper, is and are hereby required to discharge such bankrupt out of custody accordingly, and is and are hereby indemnified from any action for any escape for his, her, or their so doing.

L. Provided always, that where any person or persons shall fraudulently swear or depose, or being of the people called quakers affirm, before the commissioners, or major part of them, named in any commission of bankruptcy, or by affidavit or affirmation exhibited to him, her, or them, that a sum of money is due to him, her, or them from any bankrupt or bankrupts, which shall in fast not be really so due and owing, and shall in respect of such fictitious and pretended debt sign his, her, or their consent to the certificate for such bankrupt’s discharge from his, her, or their debts, that in every such case, unless the bankrupt shall, before the time that such major part of the said commissioners shall have signed such certificate, by writing by him to be signed and delivered to one or more of the coiiimissioners, or to one or more of the said assignees of his estate and effects under such commission, disclose the said frauds, and object to the reality of such debt, such certificate shall be null and void to all intents and purposes, and such bankrupt shall not in that case be intitled

to be discharged from his debts, or to have and receive any of the benefits or allowances given or allowed to bankrupts by this act.

CHAP. X.

An act for rendering Securities by mortgage more effectual

WHEREAS by default of the punctual payment of the interest payable upon mortgages, and on account of the great delays in bills of foreclosure, securities by mortgage are fallen into disrepute: for remedy whereof be it enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, that from and after the first day of December one thousand seven hundred and seventy two in all cases, where one year and a half’s intercll shall he due, a court of equity, upon application in manner hereafter mentioned, shall appoint a receiver to receive such part of the rents of the mortgaged premisses, as shall be sufficient to pay such arrear of interest, and also the accruing intercll of the said mortgage money from time to time, one half year when the other shall. become due, until the whole of such interest due on the said mortgage shall be discharged, and no longer, together with such fees or salary as shall be appointed by the said court for such receiver, as also the necessary costs out of pocket of such application, and that out of the sums so received such interest, salary, and costs, shall be ordered to be paid.

II. And be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, that such order shall be made upon petition and affidavit, after reasonable time given to shew cause, and whether any bill has or has not been filed, relative to the said mortgage.

IV. And whereas a number of hackney coaches, chaises, drays, carts, and cars have been licenced under one or more of the acts of parliament hereby to be repealed, and the owners of the said carts and cars did duly pay the fines on being licenced, but the poverty of the owners of kackney coaches, and hackney chaises, obliged the governors of the said work-house to take bonds for the fines payable on a certain day from the peri'on or persons applying for the licence of such coaches and chaises, least the publick might be deprived of the convenience of such carriages: and whereas the obliging such persons to take out new licences, and pay new fines in consequence of this act, would be unjust: therefore be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that each and every licence, which has been so granted, and is not yet expired, shall be deemed as good and effectual for the term in said licence contained, as if the said acts were to continue in full force.

Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, the better to prevent all tumultuous assemblies and unlawful combinations within the said city, or county of the said city, that in case any persons, to the number of seven or more, not legally authorized, shall riotously and tumultuously assemble themselves together within the said city or county of the said city, and shall not disperse themselves within one hour after the reading of this dause of this act by the mayor or either of the sheriffs, or any other justice of the peace of the said city; or in case any person or persons shall hinder or attempt to hinder the said mayor, or either of the sheriffs, or any one justice of the peace, from reading this clauseof this act to the persons so assembled as aforesaid; or in case any persons to the number of seven or more, so ' assembled as aforesaid, shall by force enter or- attempt to enter the dwelling house, warehouse, shop, cellar, yard, loft, linney, or building of any inhabitant of said city, or the county of the said city, without the consent of the possessor thereof, and without lawful authority for so doing, or shall by force enter or attempt to enter any ship, lighter, boat, bark, or vessel, lying at any of the quays of the said city, or at any other place or places in the river, or within the harbour of the said city, without lawful authority for so doing, being thereof convicted in a summary way by the oath of one or more witness or witnesses before the mayor or any justice of the peace for the said city, which oath the said mayor or any justice of the peace of said city are respectively impowered and required to administer, or by the confession of the party, every person offending herein shall suffer imprisonment not exceeding six months without bail or mainprize, and be once or oftner at the discretion of the

LIV. Whereas the mayor, sheriffs, and commonalty of the present. city of Cork are impowered by charter to elect two coroners for ment fnr «>-the county of the city of Cork: and whereas by law no adequate guineas each payment is provided for such officers for their trouble in the exe-assizes-cution of the said office of coroner: be it therefore further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that it shall and may be lawful

LV. Whereas the office of clerk of the crown of the county 30l. to of the said city of Cork is very troublesome and expensive oncrmvn dtrk-account of the great number of small felonies tried at the said assizes, the persons charged with such small felonies being extremely poor and indigent, and being generally on their acquittal discharged out of custody by the clerk of the crown of the comity of the said city of Cork without the payment of fees: be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that it shall and may be lawful to and for the grand, jury at each of the assizes, to be held in every year for the county of the said city of Cork, to present (along with other publick money) the sum of thirty pounds to be raised along with such other publick money, and to be paid to the clerk of the crown of the county of the said city of Cork for his trouble in attending and executing the said office at the said assizes.

CHAP. xxii;

An act to prebent burying dead bodies in churches.

WHEREAS the burying of dead bodies in churches is a practice very injurious to health: be it enacted by the king’s most excellent Majesty by and with the advice aid consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, that from and after the first day of August one thousand seven hundred and seventy two no person or persons shall bury any dead body, or break up any floor, ground, or pavement within the walls of any church or chapel, or chancel, ayle, room, or place thereunto belonging, under the fame roof with such church or chapel, dr within twelve feet on the outside of the walls of any church or chapel, for the purpose of burying any dead body: and that no ecclesiastical person shall perform that part of the burial service, appointed to be said at the grave of any dead person, within the walls of any church or chapel, chancel, ayle, room, or place thereunto belonging, or within twelve feet on the out-fide of the walls of any church or chapel j and that every person, who shall offend herein; shall forfeit for every such offence the sum of ten pounds, to be recovered by civil bill, by the church wardens, or either of them, or by any parishioner of the parish wherein such offence shall be committed, to be accounted for at the next vestry after the same shall be received, and laid out ini the repairs of such church or chapel.

II. Provided always, that nothing herein contained shall extend or be construed to extend to prohibit or prevent the burying in any arched vault under any church, chapel, chancel, or ayle, room, or place thereunto belonging, where the only door to such vault opefts on the outside of the Walls of such church or chapel, chancel, ayfe, room, or place.

III. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that this act shall be read in every cathedral and parish church in tins kingdom after morning prayer on every first Sunday in May, first Sunday in August, first Sunday in November, and first Sunday in February, in every year.

An act to enable the corporation for promoting and carrying on an in* land navigation in this kingdom to erect and make a lock adjoining to the long dock of the old quay in the city of Limerick.

WHEREAS ships cannot at present lie with safety in any part of the river Shannon between the New bridge and the pier adjoining to the long dock of the old quay in the said city upon account of the rapidity of the current and hardness of the ground: and whereas boats can at present pass only at certain times, and then with much difficulty and danger, from any part of the river above Baall’s bridge: and whereas the rapidity of the current between Baall’s bridge and the new bridge is so great, and frequently to do much damage to the new quays on each side of the river, which were erected at the expence of the publick, and if not prevented will probably soon destroy the fame; all which circumstances are very injurious to the trade of the said city: and whereas the said several inconveniencies may be remedied by erecting a lock across the said river from the said pier of the said long dock, and making the space between the said lock and the said New bridge a safe and convenient place for ships to lie in: be it enacted by the king's most excel- Tliecorpo. lent Majesty by and with the advice and consent of the lords ration may spiritual and temporal and commons in this present parliament® assembled, and by the authority of the same, that it shall and Shannon, may be lawful to and for the said corporation for promoting and carrying on an inland navigation in this kingdom to erect such lock, as is herein before mentioned, and to apply such part of the money granted to them by parliament, as they shall think proper for that purpose, not exceeding the sum of one thousand liamenury five hundred pounds in the whole. 8ra"U

CHAP. XXVIII.

An act for preventing the ereiling of lime kilns in the city of Dublin,

CHAP. XXIX.

An act for allowing further time to persons in offices or employments to qualify ihemjehes pursuant to an act, intitled, An act to prevent the further growth of popery.

WHEREAS several persons, well affected to his Majesty's government and the church of Ireland as by law established, may have through ignorance neglected or been prevented by ficlcness or other unavoidable causes from taking and subscribing the oaths, and making and subscribing the declaration and from receiving the sacrament of the lord's supper according to the directions of an act made in this kingdom in the focond year of the reign of her late Majesty Queen Anne, intitled. An all is prrnent the further growth of popery, and by their inadvertency may have incurred great penalties: be it enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, thaC all and every person or persons, who have incurred any penalties and incapacities in the said act, intitled. An act to prevent the further growth of popery, mentioned, by neglecting to qualify themselves according to the said act, {halt be and are hereby indemnified, freed, and discharged of and from alt incapacities, disabilities, forfeitures, and penalties incurred by reason of such omission or neglect as aforesaid; and that no ad or alls done by them, or any of them, and not yet avoided, shall be questioned ot avoided by reason of such neglect or omission, but all such acts shall be, and are hereby declared and enacted to be, as good and effectual, as if all and every such person and persons bad taken and subscribed the said oaths, and received the said sacrament, and made and subscribed the said declaration in manner as aforesaid; any thing in the said act to the contraty notwithstanding: provided such person or persons do and shall take and subscribe the said oaths, and receive the said sacrament, and make, repeat, and subscribe the said declaration, in such mannet and form, and in such place and places, as are directed and appointed by the said act to prevent the further growth of popery, on or before the first day of August, which shall be in the year of our lord one thousand seven hundred and seventy four.

2

'the eleventh and twelfth years of George III.

II. And whereas several of his Majesty's subjects are often preferred in the army refilling in Great Britain, by which they are by the laws in force in that kingdom obliged to qualify themselves in some part of Great Britain by receiving the sacrament, taking the oaths, and subscribing the declaration, within the time mentioned in Tech laws: and whereas the regiment or regiments, in which such officer or officers have commissions so granted to them, are often ordered into this kingdom, and put upon this establishment, by which a doubt has arisen, whether such officer or officers, notwithstanding he or they having qualified themselves in Great Britain for such commissions according to the said laws, are not by the laws in foroe in this kingdom obliged to qualify themselves after their arrival here for such commissions according to an act of parliament passed in this kingdom in the second year of the reign of her late Majesty queen Anne, intitled, An act to prevail the further growth of popery: be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, that no officer or officers so preferred in Great Britain, who shall have qualified him or themselves for such commission or commissions according to and within the time limited by the said laws made in Great Britain, shall be obliged to qualify him or themselves In this kingdom for such commission or commissions so granted to him or them in such regiment or regiments after their arrival in this kingdom, and being put upon this establishment; any law, usage, or custom to the contrary notwithstanding.

III. Provided always, that this act, or any thing herein contained, shall not extend to restore or intitle any person or persons to any office or employment already actually avoided by judgment of any of his Majesty's courts of record, or already filled up by any other person, but that such office or employment shall be and remain in the person or persons who is or are now intided by law to the fame, as if this act had never been made.

CHAP. XXX.

An act for bailing fuel) poor as fall be found unable to support themselves by labour, and otherwise providing for them, and jor refraining such as fall be found able to support themselves by labour or indufry from begging.

WHEREAS strolling beggars are very numerous in this kingdom: and whereas it is become equally rvecessary to give countenance and assistance to those poor who shall be found disabled by old age or infirmities to cam their living, as to restrain and punish those who may be able to support themselves by labour or indiiftry, and yet may choose to live in idleness by begging; and it is just to call upon the humane and affluent to contribute to support of real objects of charity: and whereas those purposes may be better effected by one law', than by many laws tending to the fame purpose; be it enacted by the King’s 33lL 8-c' mort excellent Majesty by and with the advice and consent of 15omiio&u the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present repealed^' parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, that one act of parliament made in this kingdom in the thirty third year injuSforce of the late King Henry the eighth, entitled, AnaBfor vaga-ZhrTtik ,n bonds, and another act made in this kingdom in the eleventh h'ommi'M year t'e iate king Charles the first, entitled. An act for erect-13A14C. 3! ing houses of correction, and for the punishing of rogues, vagabonds, e.^6./.zt. anj jifrjy beggars, and other lewd and idle persons, shall be and the same are hereby repealed and made void from the twenty fourth day of June one thousand seven hundred and seventy two.

CHAP. XXXI.

An act for enabling certain persons to carry on and compleat the grand canal.

WHEREAS several sums of money have been heretofore expended for the purpose of making an inland canal and navigation between the city of Dublin and the river Shannon; and from the difficulties attending the said undertaking, and from the several additions which it may be necessary to make thereunto, as well by continuing the same to the river Liffey and the harbour of Dublin as by opening a communication between the said canal and the navigable parts of the Barrow, and other rivers contiguous thereunto, and by malting outlets or off-branches to certain market towns adjacent to the said canal, it now appears, that a very considerable additional sum, not less than one hundred and fifty thousand pounds, mil be necessary for compleating the said navigation: and whereas the right honourable the lord mayor, sheriffs, commons, and citizens of the city of Dublin, the right honourable the earl of Drogheda, the right honourable lord Sydney, the right honourable the speaker of the Patrick Weldon, reverend Arthur Weldon, Mr. Thomas Wil-dridge, and several other persons have already associated themselves for the purpose of carrying on so useful a delign, by which the said city of Dublin may with greater certainty, and at a much cheaper rate than at present, be supplied with most of the necessaries of life, and the high roads leading to the said city (many of which are now almost impassable) will be less crowded and may more easily be kept in repair: and the said persons having engaged to subscribe several very considerable sums towards compleating the said work, it is reasonable, that they together with all future subscribers should have some adequate compensation, as well for the sums they shall so lay out, as for the hazard and labour of such a work: be it enacted by the King’s a fuMcrip most excellent Majesty by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present parlia- corporation ment assembled, and by the authority of the same, that immediately after this present act shall pass into a law, the corporation for promoting and carrying on an inland navigation in this so much as kingdom shall open a subscription for carrying on and com- "pcdicnt’ pleating the said navigations from the city of Dublin to the Shannon, or so much thereof as to the said corporation shall seem expedient: and that the said subscription shall be kept open, *t;n fooool, until the sum of sixty thousand pounds shall be subscribed for fuI>rcrib«1-the purposes aforesaid.

IX. And be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the joint (lock of the said company shall be the said sum of sixty thousand pounds, together with all such further sums (not exceeding in the whole the said sum of one hundred and fifty thousand pounds) which shall be subscribed, and upon which such payment of five per cent, shall be made within the said term of one calendar month from the time such original fub-feription shall be closed; and also such other sums as the said company at some general meeting shall judge necessary to be raised by subscription for the purpose of carrying on the said work: which sums, when subscribed, shall be added to and become a part of the joint stock of the said company.

X. And be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the joint stock of the said company shall be divided into Ihares of fifty pounds each.

XI. And whereas the said subscribers cannot enjoy the full profits of the said undertaking, until the same shall be corn-pleated $ but their monies advanced mull; for some time remain without producing any interest to themselves, and it is not reasonable, that future subscribers should reap the benefits of the said work upon the fame terms with those, who shall have borne the principal part of the hazard and toss, which at first may be incurred: be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, that if at any time after one calendar month next ensuing the doling of the said original subscription the said company shall be minded to enlarge their capital stock, and their original subscriptions shall at such time be valued above par, or at more than the sum originally subscribed, the said company may be at liberty and they are hereby empowered from time to time to cause new Ihares of fifty pounds each in the said joint stock to be made out, and to sell the same to any new subscribers at such rate as the said company shall appoint for the fame, or by publick cant; and that the said sums so subscribed shall be added to and become part of the joint stock of the said company.

CHAP. XXXIII.

An act for regulating the journeymen taylors and journeymen Shipwrights of the city of Dublin and the liberties thereof and of the county of Dublin.

WHEREAS great numbers of journeymen taylors in and about the city of Dublin and liberties thereof and in and about the county of Dublin, who have served apprenticeships, or have been brought up in the art or mystery of a taylor, have lately departed from their services without just cause, and have entered into combinations to advance their wages to unreasonable prices, and lessen their usual hours of work, which manifestly tends to the prejudice of trade, to the encouragement of idleness, and to the great increase of the poor of this metropolis: and whereas these disorders principally arise from clubs and societies formed and held in different parts of the said city and county of

Dublin, where associations are entered into* oaths administered,

and other illegal acts committed, which if not timely prevented may be productive of very ill consequences: for remedy whereof be it enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, that every person or persons, who shall knowingly permit such clubs or societies to be kept and held in his, her, or their house or apartments, shall upon conviction thereof before any two or more justices of peace for the county, wherein such person or persons shall be rciident, upon the oath of two or more credible witnesses forfeit and pay for every such offence the sum of twenty pounds, one moiety thereof to be paid to the informer, and the other moiety to be applied to the use of the blue coat hospital in the city of Dublin; and if such offender shall not be able to pay such fine, that it shall and may be lawful for the said justices by warrant under their hands and seals to commit such offender to the common gaol of the county, there to be kept without bail or main-prize for three months.

CHAP. XXXIV.

An act for the remitting of prisoners with their indiBments by the ! justices of his Majesty's court of King’s Bench to the places, where the crimes were committed.

Prisoncis WHEREAS persons, indicted for high treason and felony, mental*-" ’ ’ may remove as well their bodies as their indictments into moved into the COurt of king’s bench, if that court shall think fit, and can-

Jj, R. may be 0 7

remanded not by order of law be remitted or sent down to the justices of treason or fc- ga°l delivery or of the peace, or other justices or commissioners, lonycharged, to proceed upon them: be it therefore enacted by the King's most excellent Majesty by and with the advice and consent, of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, that in and pro- every such case the justices of the king’s bench shall have full au-c"if ferer re- thority and power by their discretions to remand and fend down moved. as well the bodies of all such persons as their indictments into the counties, where the said high treason or felony are or shall be charged in said indictments to be committed or done, and to command all justices of gaol delivery, justices of the peace, and all other justices and commissioners of oyer and terminer, and every of them, to proceed and determine upon all the aforesaid bodies and indictments so removed after the course of the common law, in such manner as the fame justices of gaol delivery, justices of the peace, and other commissioners, or any of them might or should have done, if the said prisoners or indictments had never been brought into the said king’s bench.

As a further supply for expences of government,

from 25 December 1773 to 25 December 1775 additional duties,

on chintzes, callicoes, and muslins of the Ealt, 6d. per yanl.

An act for granting to his Majesty an additional duty upon the several

goods and merchandizes therein mentioned,

WE your Majesty's most dutiful and loyal subjects, the commons of Ireland in parliament assembled, as a further supply to your Majesty to support the expences of your Majesty's government do most humbly beseech your Majesty, that it may be enacted, and be.it enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, that from and after the twenty fifth day of December one thousand seven hundred and seventy three until the twenty fifth day of December one thousand seven hundred and seventy five indufive there shall be raised, levied, collected, and paid, the several rates and additional duties herein after mentioned, .(that is to say) for and upon all chintzes, callicoes, and muslins of the manufacture of China, Periia, and the East Indies, imported into this kingdom during the time aforesaid, the sum of six pence per yard.

II. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that all and every the several and respective additional duties, rates, and impositions hereby granted, shall be raised, answered, collected, and paid unto your Majesty, your heirs and successors, during the term aforesaid at the same time, in the like manner, and by such ways, means, and methods, and by such rules and directions, and under such penalties and forfeitures, and with such powers, as are appointed, directed, arid expressed in and by an act made in this kingdom in the fourteenth and fifteenth years of the reign of his late Majesty King Charles the second, intitled. An act for the settling the excise or new impojl upon his Majesty, his heirs and successors, according to the book of rates therein inserteet, or by any other law now in force relating to the revenue of excise in this kingdom, as fully and effectually to all intents and purposes as if the fame were particularly mentioned, expressed, and enacted again in the body of this present act, with like remedy of appeal to and for the party grieved as in and by the said act of excise, or any other law or laws now in being relating to the duties of excise, is provided.

CHAP. IV.

An act to repeal an act, intitled, an all for the more effectual punishing wicked and disorderly persons, who have committed or fall commit violences, and do injuries to the persons or properties of arty of his Majestys subjects in the counties of Antrim, Down, Armagh, city and county of Londonderry, and county of Tyrone, or any of them, or who shall deliver or publish threatening letters, or who refifi or oppose the levying the publick taxes in the said counties, or any of them, and for the more effectual bringing to justice certain offenders therein mentioned.

WHEREAS an act of parliament passed in the eleventh year ,&u of his present Majesty's reign, intitled, an all for the more effectual punifing wicked and disorderly persons, who have committed orfall commit violences, and do injuries to the persons or properties of any of his Majesty's subjects in the counties of Antrim, Down, Armagh, city and county of Londonderry, and county of Tyrone, or any of them, or who shall deliver orpublish threatening letters, or who refjl or oppose the levying the publick taxes in the said counties, or any of them, and for the more effectual bringing to justice certain offenders therein mentioned, has been found to be no longer necessary: be it enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal, and commons in this present parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, that the aforesaid act, and every olause thereof, be henceforth repealed, and made null and void.

Free gift of rates and duties following,

Art aB fir granting to his Majesty, his heirs and successors, several duties upon vellum, parchment, and paper.

WE your Majesty's most dutiful and loyal subjects the commons of Ireland in parliament assembled, being desirous to raise such aids and supplies as may be sufficient to support with honour and dignity your Majesty's government, do humbly present your majesty with the free gift of the rates and duties herein after mentioned, and do beseech your Majesty, that it may be enacted, and be it enacted, by the King’s most excellent Majesty by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, that from and after the twenty fifth day of March, which shall be in the year of our Lord one thousand seven hundred and seventy four, there shall be throughout the kingdom of Ireland raised, collcfled, and paid unto his Majesty, his heirs and successors, from the twenty fifth day of Match aforesaid 'till the twenty fifth day of December, which shall be in the year one thousand seven hundred and seventy five indufive, for the several and tespective matters and things herein after mentioned, which shall be written or engrafted at any time or times from the said twenty fifth day of Match one thousand seven hundred and seventy four to the tweoty fifth day of December one thousand seven hundred and seventy five indufive, the several

XIX. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that in case any clerk, officer, or person, who in respect of any public office or employment is or shall be intided or intruded to make, engross, or write any records, deeds, indrumems, or writings, by this act charged to pay a duty as aforesaid, shall be guilty of any fraud or practice to deceive his Majesty of any duty by (his ad payable by making, engroding, or writing any such record, deed, indtument, or writing, or by cauf-ing the same to be made, engroded, or written, upon vellum, parchment, or paper, not marked or damped according to this act, or upon which there shall not be some damp or mark resembling the fame, or upon vellum, parchment, or paper, marked or damped with any mark or damp, which he shall know to be counterfeited, or by engroding or writing any such deed, indruinent, or other writing, upon vellum, parchment or paper, that shall be marked or damped for a iotder duty as aforesaid, then every such clerk, officer, or person so guilty of any such fraud or practice, and being thereof lawfully convicted, shall forfeit his office, place, or employment respectively, and be disabled to hold or enjoy the fame for the future. And if any attorney belonging to any court whatsoever shall be guilty of any such fraud or practice as aforesaid, and be convicted thereof, he shall be disabled for the future to practice as an attorney.

XX. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that if any person or persons shall write or engross, or cause to be written or engroded, either the whole or any part of any matter or thing, in respect whereof any duty is payable by this act, upon any part of any piece of vellum, parchment, or paper, whereon there shall have been before engroded, written, or printed, any other matter or thing, in respect whereof any /duty is payable by this act, before such vellum, parchment, or paper shall have been again marked or damped according to this act, or shall fraudulently etafe or ferape out, or cause to be erased or feraped out, the name or names of any person or persons, or any sum, date, or other thing engroded, written, or printed, in such indrument, writing, matter, or thing as aforesaid, or fraudulently cut, tear, or get off any mark or damp from any piece of vellum, parchment, or paper, or any part thereof, with intent to use such damp or mark for any other writing, matter, or thing, in respect whereof any duty shall be payable by virtue of this act, then so often, and in every such case, every person so offending in any of the particulars before mentioned shall for every such offence forfeit the sum of fifty pounds.

And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that from and after the twenty fourth day of June one thousand and seventy four no common distiller of spirits for sale shall alter or permit, or suffer the situation, position, or dipping place of any back or cooler, by him or her made use of, to be altered, after the fame has been fixed by the proper officer, without first giving notice thereof in writing to the surveyor, or other officer of excise of the disttict ordivision, wherein he or she shall reside, under the penalty of five pounds sterling for every such offence, the same to be recovered and levied in manner herein after mentioned.

XI. And whereds many frauds have been practised in the carriage of spirits and strong waters from the places, where they were distilled, to the place or places where the fame were intended to be sent, or alledged to be lent: for remedy whereof be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, that from and after the twenty fourth day of June one thousand seven hundred and seventy four all permits or let passes for the carriage of spirits or strong waters from one place to another shall express the ehriftian and sirname of the person or persons, to whom the same shall be sent or consigned, and the place of his or their residence; and the spirits, or strong waters, mentioned in such permit or let pass, shall be delivered as directed in such permit or let pass, and at no other place or places whatsoever; and if such {pints or strong waters shall be delivered to any other person, except the person or persons mentioned in such permit or let pass, or his or their known servants, or at any other place or places than those mentioned in such permit or let pass, or if afterwards carried from the place of the first delivery to any other place without renewal of the permit, then, and in either of the said cases, the spirits or strong waters, and the calk and vessel in which the same are contained, shall be forfeited, in the same manner as if no permit had been at any time granted for the same.

Provided also, and be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, that this aS or any thing herein contained shall not extend to subject any person or persons, who shall carry raw and unmanufactured wool or frizes, or worsted or woollen Itockings, from one part of the kingdom to another, or expose the same to sale in any fair, market, or other place in this kingdom, to any of the duties or penalties herein before mentioned, so as such person or persons shall not at the same time carry or expose to sale any other wares, goods, or merchandizes, except the said raw and unmanufactured wool, and the said frizes and worsted and woollen dockings.

XIII. Provided also, and be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, that this acr, or any thing herein contained, shall not extend to subject any person or persons; who shall carry any pots or griddles made of call iron or metal from one part of the kingdom to another, or expose the same to sale in any fair, market, or other place in this kingdom, to the payment of any greater duty than the Turn of twenty shillings by the year in the whole, although such person or persons shall or may trade ot travel with one or more horse or horses, or other beast or beasts drawing or bearing burthen, so as such person or persons shall not at the same time carry or expose to sale any other goods, wares or merchandizes, except the said pots and griddles made of call iron metal.

Provided, also, and be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, that it shall and may be lawful to and for the commissioners of his Majesty's revenue, or any three or more of them for the time being, to orderand direct to be paid out of the monies raised by this act to the said collectors, their clerks, or any other persons, such sums of money as they or any of them shall or may icafonably deserve for their service, or shall or may have expended in the execution of or in relation to this act.

XVI. Provided also, and be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, that this act or any thing herein contained shall not extend or be construed to give any power for licensing any hawker, pedlar, or petty chapman to sell or expose to sale any wares or merchandizes in any city, borough, town corporate, or market town within this realm, any otherwise than he or flic might have done before the making of this act, any thing herein contained to the contrary notwithstanding.

CHAP. XII.

An act for continuing and amending three several acts, one passed in the reign of his late Majesty King George the second, and the other two in his frefent Majesty's reign, for making the river Lagan navigable and opening a communication by water between Lougbneagh and the town of Belfast; and for enabling the commissioners therein named, to raise money by alignment of said duties for the more expeditious and effectual carrying on said work.

WHEREAS by an act passed in the twenty seventh year of the reign of his late Majesty King George the second of glorious memory certain duties, rates, and impositions were granted to his said late Majesty King George the second for the use of the corporation for promoting and carrying on an inland navigation in Ireland, to be by them laid out and expended in making the river Lagan navigable, and opening a passage by water between Loughneagh and the town of Belfast in the county of Antrim; and the said act was afterwards continued and amended by an act passed in the third year of his present most gracious Majesty George the third, and both said acts were by an act passed in the eleventh and twelfth years of his present Majesty's reign continued for nine years from the twenty fifth day of December one thousand seven hundred and seventy three; and by the said act the local commissioners for said navigation in order to expedite the finishing of said work are enabled to raise money by assignment of the said dudes for the said term of nine years; but from the shortness of said term it is found, that money sufficient to answer said purposes cannot be obtained or borrowed upon any assignment of the said duties during such term; and it therefore becomes necessary to answer the intention of the said act, to enlarge the said term, in order thereby to enable the said commissioners to borrow money for compleating in a short time the said navigation; An act for allowing further time to persons in offices or employments to qualify themselves pursuant to an act, intitled, an act to prevent the further growth of popery.

WHEREAS several persons well afteflcJ to his Majesty's government and Indemnity on the church of Ireland, as by law established, may have through ignorance Ami,

neglected, or been prevented by sickness or other unavoidable causes, from raking c. 6, by i Aug. and subscribing the oaths, and making and subscribing the declaration, and from receiving the sacrament of the Lord's supper, according to the directions of an act made in this kingdom in the second year of the reign of her late Majesty Queen Ann, intitled, an act [9prevent the further growth cf popery, and by their inadvertency may have incurred great penalties: be it enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritua) and temporal, and commons in this present parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, that all and every person or persons, who have incurred any penalties or incapacities in the said act, intitled, an act to prevent the growth of popery, mentioned, by neglecting to qualify themselves according to the said act, shall be and are hereby indemnified, freed, and discharged of and from all incapacities, disabilities, forfeitures and penalties incurred by reason of such omission or neglect as aforesaid; and that no act or acts done by them or any of them, and not yet avoided, shall be questioned or avoided by reason of such neglect or omission, but all such acts shall be and are hereby declared and enacted to be as good and cffcftuaf, as if all and every such person and persons had taken and subscribed the said oaths, and received the salt! sacrament, and made and subscribed the said declaration in manner as aforesaid j arty thing in the said act to the contrary notwithstanding; provided such person or persons do and shall take and subscribe the said oaths, and receive the said sacrament, and make,.repeat, and subscribe the faic declaration, in such manner and form, and in such place and places, as are directed and appointed by the said act to prevent the further growth of popery, on or before, the firfk day of August, which shall be in the year of our Lord one thousand seven hundred and seven’y five.

And whereas by an act passed in the eleventh and twelfth years of his present Majesty, intitled, An act for better regulating the foundling hospital and work house in the city of Dublin, and increas.ng the fund for the support thereof; also for making a provision for appointing a locum tenens in case of the death of the lord mayor or the president of the court of conscience, it is among other things enacted, that the governors of the said hospital, eleven at lead: being present, shall have power and authority from time to time to licence all such persons, as shall own, keep, or drive any cart, car, or other carriage, that shall bring into the said city or the liberties thereof, be it for hire or sale, or otherwise, any bricks, stones, sand, gravel, lime, or other materials employed or made use of in building or paving, and that for every such cart, car, or other carriages, the sum of twenty shillings be paid by way of fine: And whereas it is found inconvenient, that carts, cars, or other carriages, which are not employed to carry for sale or hire any of the aforesaid materials into the said city or liberties, should be obliged to take out licences as aforesaid: be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, that it shall and may be lawful to and for any person or persons whatsoever, who shall have any cart, car, or other carriage, employed in bringing into the said city any bricks, stones, land, gravel, lime, or other materials usually employed in building or paving for their own use, and not for sale or hire, to use the fame in manner aforesaid without taking out any licence whatsoever, any thing in the herein before in part recited act in any wise notwithstanding.

CHAP. XIX.

An act for the better and mm certain valuation of houses in counties of cities and counties of towns.

An act for amending an aB passed in the third year of his Majesty's reign, entitled, An act for the better regulation of the linen and hempen manufactures,

WHEREAS by an act passed in the third year of his Majesty's reign for the better regulation of the linen, and hempen manufactures lappers of white or bleached linen or hempen cloth are to be appointed in manner and under and subject to the rules, orders, and directions therein mentioned: and whereas many pieces of linen and hempen cloth, bleached or in part bleached, have lately been stolen out of several bleach greens in this kingdom, and it hath been found very difficult for die owners thereof to prove their property in the fame: for remedy whereof be it enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, that from and after the twenty fourth day of June one thousand seven hundred and seventy four no person shall expose to sale any piece or part of a piece of linen or hempen cloth, which has been bleached or in part bleached, unless the name of some lapper appointed or to be appointed as aforesaid, and also the name of the county wherein such lapper shall reside at the time of marking such piece or part of a piece, shall be marked at one end thereof with Vermillion or done blue and size; and that if any person shall expose to sale any piece or part of a piece of linen or hempen cloth, not having such names marked thereon in manner aforesaid, such person shall for every such offence forfeit the sum of five pounds, to be recovered and disposed of in the same manner as is by the said act directed with regard to all penalties and forfeitures therein mentioned, not exceeding in value the sum of six pounds, and also such piece or part of a piece of linen or hempen cloth; and that if any person shall counterfeit the name of any lapper, appointed or to be appointed as aforesaid, to any piece or part of

The thirteenth and fourteenth years of George ID.

of a piece of linen or hempen cloth, such person being thereof lawfully convicted shall be condemned to Hand in the pillory, or to be transported for the term of seven years to some one of his Majesty's plantations abroad, at the discretion of the judge or judges who shall try such offence.

II. And be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, that no money shall be granted or paid by the trustees of the linen and hempen manufactures for or on account of any mill, bleach green, or other work to be executed by any individual, or as a bounty to enable him to carry on any branch of the manufacture j but that every part of the fund under their direction shall be applied in payment of utensils, of premiums for the railing of flax, of the several officers and servants necessarily employed by or attending on the said trustees, or at the linen and yarn halls, and in bounties or premiums on such species of the manufactures as shall be previously ascertained from time to time by the said trustees, and which shall be brought to market or exported.

III. Provided always, that this shall not extend to prevent or restrain the said trustees from making good any pomife or engagement, entered into by them previous to the first day of March one thousand seven hundred and seventy four.

IV. XVI. And whereas Plunket street in the parish of St. Nicholas without the walls of the said city has been upwards of seventy

years the only market or place for the sale of doaths for the lower not removed* class of people, and that all the houses and shops in the said street have pent-hdufes, shop-windows, and frames, which jet out into the said street for the better exposing to sale the said cloaths; therefore be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, that no powers, granted by this bill to the commissioners or committees, shall extend to the removing pent-houses, shop-windows, or frames, which jet out irt the said street, as it will greatly injure the said market, and ruin the trade thereof, to the great prejudice and loss of a great number of industrious people.

CHAP. XXIII.

An act for the better regulation of the admiffwn and practice of attornies.

WHEREAS the admission of attornies in the courts of king’s bench, common pleas, and exchequer in this kingdom is of the greatest consequence and concern to the publick in general, and particularly to the suitors in the said courts, and whereas it has heretofore been a frequent practice among the inferior class of attornies of said courts to take apprentices of low education, whose circumstances or condition of fortune frequently induce them to be guilty of mean and improper practices to the dishonour of the profession, and to the great injury
