And whereas many inconveniencies and mischiefs have frequently arisen and daily arise to suitors and others, by reason that persons, who have been legally admitted attornies of the courts, but who afterwards resided intirely or for the most part in the country, do there in like manner take apprentices from amongst the lower class of the people without education as aforesaid, or any neams of subsisting themselves, and cause them to be ("worn attornies of the said courts, where it often happens, they never after appear, but become common barreters or promoters of suits especially amongst labouring and industrious poor people, to the impoverishing and ruin of them and their families: and whereas several attornies, who attend the said courts at Dublin, suffer persons not qualified to prosecute and defend suits both at law and in equity in the said courts in their names, whereby great injury does arise to the suitors and to the publick: therefore be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, that no person Noappren- whatsoever, hereafter to be bound an apprentice to an attorney of attorney *tteJ any of liie said courts, shall be admitted an attorney thereof, unless he shall make appear to the judges of the court, in which he so applies to be admitted, by affidavit or affidavits to be filed in the proper office, or an attested copy or attested copies thereof, (for the filing and copy of which the sum of two shillings, as\>yjG.i. and no more, shall be paid) or in such other manner as such r. 5. and that judges shall for that purpose appointor direct, that as well the ceding8 the attorney, to whom he shall so have been bound, Audi have served, ing^attenScd accol'ding to the aforesaid act of the seventh of George the second, the courts j as also that the said person so applying to be admitted shall have tamj a year. ^ ^)ace years next |,efore the time of such applica-

CHAP. XXVI.

An act for enforcing a due execution of tie laws relative to turnpike roads in this kingdom.

WHEREAS turnpike roads are become general in this kingdom, and it is of great moment to the inland commerce of and the intercourse within this kingdom, that the laws heretofore made, and those that shall hereafter be made, for the levying of tolls for the making and repairing those roads, be duly and faithfully executed: be it enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, that the treasurers of the turnpike roads in this kingdom respectively shall on or before the first day of October one thousand seven hundred and seventy four deposite with the clerks of the peace of the counties respectively, through which the turnpike roads of this kingdom or any parts thereof are carried, full, true, and fair copies of all contracts made with the commissioners of the said turnpike roads respectively, for making and repairing the said roads respectively or any bridges on them, and all the orders made by the commissioners or a competent number of the commissioners of the turnpike roads of this kingdom respectively for any purpose or purposes whatsoever, any ways relative to the said turnpike roads respectively, down to the said first day of October one thousand seven hundred and seventy four; and all such contracts and orders as aforesaid, to be made after that day, within one calendar month after the making of the fame, and after the first of October one thousand seven hundred and seventy four yearly and every year on every first day of October the full annual produce of the toll of the turnpike roads of this kingdom respectively, and the expences of collecting the same.

II. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that every treasurer of any turnpike board in this kingdom, who shall fail to comply with the said orders hereby given, or with any of them, shall forfeit the sum of twenty pounds for every calendar month, during which he shall fail after the times aforesaid respectively to comply with the said orders, or any of them; which said penalty or penalties shall be sued for by civil bill, levied, and recovered, as is directed, and by the same rules in all respects, given by the laws which have created that judicature in the cases provided for by those laws, in the name of the clerk of the crown of that county where the civil bill ought to be brought;

CHAP. XXX.

An act for amending the road from Dundalk to Drnleer in the county of Louth.

XIV. And whereas the roads in this kingdom are very much damaged by the narrow wheels of cars, carts, and drays, and by the streaks being set on such wheels with sprigs or high headed nails: for preventing of which be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid,' that from the twenty fourth day of June one thousand seven hundred and seventy four every owner or driver1 of any cart, car, dray, or waggon, the wheels of which shall be of leis breadth or gauge than three inches at the lead from fide to fide at the bottom or foie, when worn, and when the streaks or iron, with which such wheels are bound, shall be set on with sprigs or high headed nails, shall forfeit the sum of five shillings and five pence, as also such cart, car, dray, or waggon, whenever any such cart, car, dray or waggon shall be used or drawn on any publick road in this kingdom, to the person seizing the fame; for the recovery whereof it shall be lawful for any person to seize any such carriage, as also any horse or bcaft of draft in such car, cart, dray, or waggon, with all the harness or accoutrements thereunto belonging, with all convenient speed, deliver up the said horse, or beast of draft, into the custody of the constable, pound-keeper, or parish officer of the fame or of the adjacent parish or liberty, where such seizure shall be made, who are hereby required to receive and retain the fame for the space of twenty four hours, unless sooner delivered by virtue of a war-

XIV. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the toll or duty hereby granted shall take place and have continuance only from and after the first day of June next for and during the term of forty one years.

XV. Provided nevertheless, that if at any time before the expiration of the said forty one years all parts of the said road shall be sufficiently amended and repaired, and shall be so adjudged by the authority of the said trustees, appointed or hereafter to be cholen by virtue of this act, by an adjudication under their hands and seals, that then from and after such adjudication made the said tolls and duties shall cease and determine, any thing herein contained to the contrary notwithstanding.

XVI. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the said trustees, or any seven or more of them, shall meet at Ennis on the last Monday in May next, and the said trustees shall then adjourn themselves, and afterwards meet there, or at any other place or places near the said highways or roads to be repaired, as the said trustees, or any five or more of them shall think proper or convenient, as often as it shall be neceslkry, for the putting this act in execution. And if it shall happen there shall not appear at any meeting, which shall be appointed to be had or held by the said trustees, a sufficient number of trustees to act at such meeting, and to adjourn to any other day, then and in such case the clerk to the said trustees shall by notice in writing to be affixed at the respective gates or turnpikes at least ten days before the said meeting, appoint the said trustees to meet at the house, where the meeting of said trustees

eel to enable his Majesty's subjects of whatever perfuaften to tef-tify their allegiance to him.

CHAP. XXXVI. 1773-4.

An act for amending and continuing anaftpaffed in the ninth year of his late Majesty King George the second, entitled, An act for repairing the road leading from the town of Armagh in the county of Armagh to the town of Notary in the county of Down,

CHAP. XXXVII.

An act for preventing frauds in the measurement oj lime.

WHEREAS lime is now become-of general use throughout this kingdom in the manuring and improvement of lands, and it will be highly advantageous to agriculture to prevent frauds in the sale thereof: be it enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty by and with the advice and coofent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, that from and after the first day of May one thousand feveri hundred and seventy four no lime whatsoever shall be fold otherwise than by measure; and that every vessel, wherein it shall be measured, shall be stamped or sealed by some magistrate or other publick officer of some corporate or market town in the county, where the said lime shall be measured, or the next adjoining county Voi. CHAP. XXXVIII.

An act to prevent the importation of mines in casks under the size of thirty one gallons, except as herein excepted.

WHEREAS great quantities of different kinds of wines have been lately imported into this kingdom in final! casks or vessels, with an intent that the fame might be more eastiy and privately carried off and conveyed away without paying the duties payable thereon: for prevention whereof be it enacted by the king!* most excellent Majesty by and with the advice and confenc of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, that from and after the twenty fourth day of June one thousand seven hundred and seventy four no wines shall be imported or brought into this kingdom, or into any port, harbour, haven, or creek thereof, in any cask or vessel, which shall not contain thirty one gallons at least, from any place whatsoever, upon pain of forfeiting the said wines and the value thereof, together with the cask or vessel in which such wines shall be contained.

XI. XII. And whereas the said act for badging the poor in this kingdom extends only to the creating of corporations, for the purposes of the said act, within counties at large, or in counties of cities, or counties of towns in this kingdom: and whereas the town of Belfast in the county of Antrim is a populous and wealthy town, and the said town and parish thereof contains as many inhabitants as several of the cities or counties of towns in this kingdom, but, not being a county within itself, cannot have the benefit of the said law in as ample and full a manner, as is found necessary: and whereas the inhabitants of the said town and parish of Belfast have by voluntary subscriptions and contribution raised a fund of money for the support of the poor within the said town and parish, and for the better answering that laudable intention have erected a poor house and infirmary for the reception of the said poor and of lick persons on certain grounds adjoining to the said town, which have been granted by the right honourable Arthur earl of Donegall to certain trustees for the uses aforesaid; and the said inhabitants are desirous, that the said hospital and infirmary, and the grounds whereon the same are built, so granted by the said earl of Donegall to said trustees herein after named, and that a body corporate should be formed, and to continue for ever, for the better carrying into execution under proper regulations tire charitable and humane design of maintaining the poor of the said town and parish: be it enacted by the authority

XVI. And whereas by an act made in the seventh and eighth years of his Majesty's reign, entitled, An att for the further improvement oj his Majestys revenue, and jor continuing and amending several acts therein particularly mentioned, it was amongst other things enacted, that there should be payable to his Majesty, his heirs and successors, for every licence to be granted for felling aquavit a, or any kind of strong waters or spirits whatsoever, by retail in any city, town corporate, and the liberties of the fame, such sum, as should be agreed to be paid for such licence pursuant to the directions of an act of the seventeenth and eighteenth of his late Majesty king Charles the second, in laid act recited, so as none do pay less than the sum of four pounds yearly, and none be compelled to pay more than five pounds yearly: and whereas it has been found by experience, that in many instances the sum of four pounds is a greater sum, than several persons applying for licences can afford to pay, which has considerably diminished his Majesty's revenue: therefore be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, that from and after the passing of this act it shall and may be lawful to and for the chief commissioners of excise, or the major part of them, to issue and grant licences for the felling of spirits and strong waters by retail in all towns corporate and the liberties thereof in this kingdom for such sum, as they in their discretion shall think fitting and reasonable under the circumstances of the case; so as no licence be granted for a less sum than three pounds yearly, nor a greater sum required or taken than five pounds yearly; the said recited act, or any other law, to the contrary notwithstanding.

XXVI. And whereas the importing of tobacco stalks into this kingdom is productive of great frauds to the diminution of his Majesty's revenue, and the detriment of the fair trader: in order to prevent the fame be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, that from and after the twenty fourth day of June in the year of our lord one thousand seven hundred and seventy fix no tobacco stalks or stems stripped from the leaf shall be imported into this kingdom under penalty of the forfeiture of the fame, or the value thereof.

XXVII. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that from and after the said twenty fourth day of June one thousand seven hundred and seventy fix all tobacco stalks or stems in any package whatsoever shall be seized and forfeited, if found on board any ship, vessel, or boat, in any port or harbour in this kingdom, or hovering within three leagues of this kingdom, or shall be discovered so to have been, although bulk shall not appear to have been broke, or any of the said tobacco stalks or stems run, or attempted to have been run, out of such ship, vessel, or boat, save only and except such tobacco stalks or stems as have been stripped from tobacco legally imported into this kingdom, and for which his Majesty's full duties shall have been paid, and have been put on board any ship, boat, or vessel to be sent coastways by cocket from one port to another in this kingdom.

XXVIII. And be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, that from and after the last mentioned twenty fourth day of June all tobacco stalks and stems, which shall be seized and legally condemned, and which after condemnation will not fell publickly for the full duties payable to his Majesty, shall be burned, or otherwise destroyed; and that the commissioners of his Majesty's revenue may, if they shall think fit, cause tire officer, or other person making such seizure, to be rewarded, in such manner as they shall think proper, such reward not to exceed one penny fir pound weight, in lieu of all other allowances.

II. And be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, that every returning officer or officers, who shall have appointed a deputy, may from time to time during the poll, as he shall think proper, remove such deputy, and appoint another person deputy in his room; and that such deputy shall, upon notice given to him by the returning officer each day, close his poll book, and deliver in the fame immediately to said officer, who shall tot up therefrom the number of votes polled on said day for each candidate, and cause the tot thereof for each candidate to be read aloud, and entered in his poll book in open court; and if such deputy shall refuse to deliver his poll book, when required by the returning officer, or shall continue to take the poll, after he shall have been directed by him to (lop, and before he shall be again directed by him to proceed, or after his deputation shall be revoked, he shall forfeit the sum of five hundred pounds; (to be recovered by any person, who will sue for the same in any of his Majesty's courts of record, to and for the use of such person filing) and every vote admitted by him after such refusal, direction to llop, or revocation, shall be considered null and void to all intents; but the person, who gave such vote, is not thereby disabled to give his vote at such election before the sheriff or other returning officer.

III. Provided always, and be it enacted, that such removal and new appointment of a deputy, and such notices to the said deputy to close the poll and deliver up the book, shall be made publickly and proclaimed in the place, where such deputy respectively shall take the poll, by the sheriff or under sheriff, or some person to be appointed for that purpose by the sheriff.

IV. And be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, that if any person or persons shall violently and outrageously disturb the court, or other assembly duly holden for the election of a member or members to serve in parliament, or interrupt the proceeding of the poll, such disturbance or riot shall not be any excuse to the returning officer, nor afford him any pretence for closing the poll j or making a return, but the court or other such assembly as aforesaid shall thereupon be adjourned for some convenient time, as the occasion may require; and, if it should be necessary, shall be further continued by adjournment from time time, till such disturbance shall have ceased, when such returning officer shall return, and again proceed on taking the poll; and every person, who shall be convicted of having violently and outrageously disturbed the court so as to interrupt the proceeding of the poll, or of having wilfully effaced, obliterated, tom,

IV. And whereas the mother church of the parish of Armani hath been in ruins for a time past the memory of man, m!> much that the feite of said church cannot at this day be iitfi-ciently ascertained: and whereas the cathedral church of faint Patrick’s, situate in the city of Armagh, hath been hitherto mad: use of from its convenient situation to all parts of said parish to serve for all the legal purposes of a parish chuicii within said parish: be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, that all acts, had and done heretofore in said cathedral church at the mother church of said parish, shall be and are hereby declared to be as good and valid in law to all intents and purposes, as if the said cathedral church had been the mother church of said parish and that for the future the said cathedral church of faint Patrick’s, Armagh be deemed and taken to be the mother church of said parish of Armagh for all legal purposes whatsoever within the said parish without prejudice to the rights, privileges or immunities, of said cathedral; and also saving to his grace the lord archbishop of Armagh, his successors, and the don and chapter of said cathedral, and their successors, their several and respective and distinct rights, privileges, and immunities in said cathedral; any thing in this act contained to the contrary in any wise notwithstanding.

CHAP. XIX.

An att fir the improvement of the ffieries of this kingdom,

WHEREAS the fisheries, carried on by the subjects of his Majesty's dominions in Europe, have been found to b: the best nurseries for able and experienced Teamen, always ready to man the royal navy when occasions require; and it is therefore of the highest national importance to give all due encouragement to the said fisheries, and to endeavour to secure the annual return of the fishermen, Tailors, and others employed therein, to the ports of his Majesty's said dominions at the end of every fishing season: now in order to promote these great and important purposes, and with a view in the first place to induce his Majesty's subjects to proceed early from the ports of this kingdom to the banks of Newfoundland, and thereby to prosecute the fishery on the said banks to the greatest advantage, be it enacted by the king’s most excellent Majesty by and with the advice and con-fentof the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, that from and after the first day of January one thousand seven hundred and seventy fix the respective bounties herein after mentioned shall be paid and allowed annually for eleven years for a certain number of ships or vessels employed in the British fishery on the banks of Newfoundland, under the limitations and restrictions herein after mentioned, that is to say, such vessels as shall appear by their register to be British built, and owned by his Majesty's subjects refuting in Great Britain or Ireland, and shall be of the burthen of fifty tons, or upwards, and navigatid with no less than fifteen men each, three fourths of whom besides the master shall be his Majesty's subjects, and in other respects qualified, and subject to the same rules and restrictions, as are described by an act made in Great Britain in the tenth and eleventh years of the reign of the late King William the third, entitled, An act to encourage the trade to Newfoundland, and shall be fitted and cleared out from some port in Ireland, after the first of January one thousand seven hundred and seventy fix, and after that day in each succeeding year, and shall proceed to the banks of Newfoundland; and having catched a cargo of fifii upon those banks, confiding of no less than ten thousand fish by tale, shall land the fame at one of the ports on the south caftcrn fide of the island of Newfoundland between Cape Ray and Cape de G’«:

CHAP. XXI.

jin aB to prevent and punish tumultuous risings of persons within this kingdom, and for other purposes therein mentioned.

Riotoui assembling of White Boys

injuring persons and property, taking horsesand arms, compelling to quit abode, imposing oaths and declarations,

threats and incendiary letters,

obft rutting export, deft (Dying corn, Ice.

WHEREAS it has frequently happened of late years in different parts of this kingdom, that several persons calling themselves White Boys and others as well by night as in the day time have in a riotous, disorderly, and tumultuous manner assembled together, and have abused and injured the persons, habitations, and properties of many of his Majesty's loyal and faithful subjects, and have taken and carried away their horles and arms, and have compelled them to surrender up, quit, and leave their habitations, farms, and places of abode, and have with threats and violence imposed sundry oaths and solemn declarations contrary to law,- and solicited several of his Majesty's subjects by threats and promises to join with them in such their mischievous and iniquitous proceedings, and have also sent threatening and incendiary letters to several persons to the great terror of his Majesty's peaceable subjects, and have taken upon themselves to obstruct the exportation of corn, grain, meal, malt, and flour, 3 and

The fifteenth and sixteenth years of George III. 78 5

and to destroy or damage the fame when intended for expor- A.D. tation, and have also destroyed mills, granaries, and storehouses 1775-6. provided for the keeping of com 5 which, if not effectually pre- Chap. 21. vented, must become dangerous to the general peace of this king- ^dangoroui dom and his Majesty's government therein: and whereas for put- <° Publick ting a flop to and punishing such enormous outrages and offences P"K’ an act passed in this kingdom in the fifth and sixth years of the reign of his present Majesty, entitled, An act to prevent jortbefuture_^C-3-c. 8. tumultuous rijings of persons "within this kingdom, and for other pur- 1 ’ fifes therein mentioned j which act hath been from time to time continued and is now in force, but hath been found inefficient for the purposes thereby intended, and for preventing and punishing such wicked and unlawful practices: be it enacted by the King's most excellent Majesty by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, that no person or persons shall be indicted, or suffer any pains or no indict-penalties, under the said receited act passed in the fifth and sixth jJXr offence years of his present Majesty's reign, for any offence which shall he committed by him, her, or them from and after the first day of March one thousand seven hundred and seventy fix; but that force» nothing herein contained shall be construed to take away any of1 the force or effect.of said statute, so far as it relates to offences, which have been committed or which shall be committed on or before the said day.

III. And be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, that from and after the first day of March one thousand seven hundred and seventy fix if any person or persons rising or assembling in manner herein before mentioned, or in any other manner whatsoever save as herein after is declared, shall either by day or by night wilfully or maliciously shoot at, maim, or disfigure any person or persons in any dwelling house or other place, or shall knowingly fend any letter with or without any fictitious name or names thereto subscribed, demanding any money, fire arms, am. munition, or other thing or things, or threatening to injure the person or property of any of his Majesty's subjects 5 or if any person or persons shall by gift, promise, or threats procure any of his Majesty's subjects to join in any of the aforesaid offences, or shall unlawfully compel, or by force, threats, or menaces attempt to compel, any of his Majesty's subjects to quit his, her, or their habitation, farm, possession, place of abode, or lawful employment, all and every person and persons so offending, being thereof lawfully convicted, shall be adjudged guilty of felony, and shall suffer death as in cases of felony without benefit of clergy.

IV. And be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, that from and after the first day of March one thouiknd seven hundred and seventy fix if any person or persons shall at any time after fun set and before fun rife, or before the hour of fix in the forenoon though the fun should be arisen, maliciously assault or in any manner whatsoever maliciously injure the habitation, property, goods, or chattles of any other person or persons, or shall force-ably and maliciously break into his, her, or their house, bam, or out house, or shall maliciously cause any door to be open by threats, menaces, or shall forceably take or carry away any horse, gelding, mare, or mule, or any gun, sword, or other offensive weapon, or any money, or goods, or chattles, without the consent of the owner, or shall cause the fame, or any of the fame, to be delivered to them by threats or menaces, all and every person or persons so offending, being thereof lawfully convicted, shall be adjudged guilty of felony, and shall suffer death as in cases of felony without the benefit of clergy.

CHAP. XXIII.

An act for the relief of the out pensioners of the hospital of King Charles the second for antient and maimed officers and soldiers of the army of Ireland.

WHEREAS the out pensioners of the hospital of King To prevent Charles the second for antient and maimed officers and lbldiers of the army of Ireland have of late suffered great im- "'y " politions and distresses from the fraudulent practices of money lenders, front whom the said out pensioners frequently take up money on terms many times moll usurious and oppressive: for the prevention of all which abuses and mischiefs be it enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, that all assignments, bargains, sales, contracts, orders, a(ngnmcms letters or powers of attorney, irrevocable, or conveying interest, &c. agrre-and agreements or securities whatsoever, made by any out pen- "u‘‘c"by' fioner, for, upon, or in respect of any sum or sums of money due, pmfioner or to become due, for or on account of the pension of the said duVoiTpcn. hospital, to such out pensioners as have been or shall be admitted r‘on’V0lJ' thereunto, shall from and after the twenty fourth day of June in the year of our lord one thousand seven hundred and seventy fix be absolutely null and void to all intents and purposes.

Whereas in and by the said act of the thirteenth and fourteenth of his present Majesty it is enacted, that the building called the Meath hospital, situated as in said act is mentioned, shall from and after the twenty fourth day of June one thousand fever* hundred'and seventy four be created, founded, erected, and established the hospital or infirmary for the county of Dublin: but a doubt hath been conceived, whether the provision thereby made as to the bodies corporate and governors thereby mentioned and provided for, or in respect of the several infirmaries and hospitals in the several counties mentioned in an act made in the fifth year of his present Majesty touching county hospitals therein mentioned, doth extend to the said hospital lately called Meath hospital, and now the county hospital, under the present circumstances thereof: therefore be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, that his grace the lord archbishop of Armagh for the time being, the lord high chancellor for the time being, the bishop of the diocese, and the rector or vicar of the parish in which the said hospital, heretofore and now called as aforesaid, is situated, and also every donor and contributor to the said hospital as herein after mentioned, shall be a body corporate, governors and governor, of the said hospital, with like powers as the governors of other county hospitals in the said act of the fifth year of his present Majesty; and that as to the donors and contributors to the said hospital they shall be governors as follows; (that is to say) every donor of any sum not less than ten pounds shall be a perpetual member and governor j and every person, who shall subscribe and pay annually for the use of the said hospital one guinea, shall be a member of the said body corporate and governor for one year from the time of such subscription and payment, and no longer.
